body.p: The number of days (X) after mailout it takes a utility company to receive payment for a customer’s bill is a normal random variable with a mean of 31 days and a standard deviation of 6 days.
The latest 2.5% of bills will be received more than how many days after mailout?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This value is 3 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid after 13 days is much greater than 2.5%. Recall that for a normal random variable 99.7% of observations will lie within 3 standard deviations of the mean, and 0.3% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Incorrect. This value is 2 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid after 19 days is much greater than 2.5%. Recall that for a normal random variable 95% of observations will lie within 2 standard deviations of the mean, and 5% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Incorrect. This value is 1 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid after 25 days is much greater than 2.5%. Recall that for a normal random variable 68% of observations will lie within 1 standard deviations of the mean, and 32% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.
Incorrect. This value is the mean, so the percent of bills paid after 31 days is 50%.

Incorrect. This value is 1 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid after 37 days is 16%. Recall that for a normal random variable 68% of observations will lie within 1 standard deviations of the mean, and 32% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Correct. This value is 2 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid after 43 days is 2.5%. Recall that for a normal random variable 95% of observations will lie within 2 standard deviations of the mean, and 5% will lie outside this range.This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Incorrect. This value is 3 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid after 13 days is only 0.15%. Recall that for a normal random variable 99.7% of observations will lie within 3 standard deviations of the mean, and 0.3% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

body.p: The number of days (X) after mailout it takes a utility company to receive payment for a customer’s bill is a normal random variable with a mean of 31 days and a standard deviation of 6 days.
The probability is 0.997 that a bill will be received between which of the following number of days?

response.feedback: Correct. Recall that for a normal random variable 99.7% of observations will lie within three standard deviations of the mean (MEAN ± 3 * SD). So, 31 − 3 (6) = 13 and 31 + 3(6) = 49 is the correct range.

Incorrect. Recall that for a normal random variable 99.7% of observations will lie within three standard deviations of the mean. It appears you calculated the values two standard deviations from the mean.

Incorrect. Recall that for a normal random variable 99.7% of observations will lie within three standard deviations of the mean. It appears you calculated the values one standard deviation from the mean.

body.p: The number of days (X) after mailout it takes a utility company to receive payment for a customer’s bill is a normal random variable with a mean of 31 days and a standard deviation of 6 days.
There is a probability of 0.50 that a bill will be received later than days after mailout.

response.feedback: Incorrect. This value is 3 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the probability of bills paid after 13 days is much greater than than 0.50. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.

Incorrect. This value is 2 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the probability of bills paid after 19 days is much greater than 0.50. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.

Incorrect. This value is 1 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the probability of bills paid after 13 days is greater than 0.50. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.
Correct. This value is the mean, so the percent of bills paid after 31 days is 50%. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.

Incorrect. This value is 1 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the probability of bills paid after 37 days is less than 0.50. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.

Incorrect. This value is 2 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the probability of bills paid after 43 days is much less than 0.50. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.

Incorrect. This value is 3 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the probability of bills paid after 49 days is much less than 0.50. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.

body.p: The number of days (X) after mailout it takes a utility company to receive payment for a customer’s bill is a normal random variable with a mean of 31 days and a standard deviation of 6 days.
About 16% of bills will be received earlier than days after mailout.

response.feedback: Incorrect. This value is 3 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid earlier than 13 days is much less than 16%. Recall that for a normal random variable 99.7% of observations will lie within 3 standard deviations of the mean, and 0.3% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Incorrect. This value is 2 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid earlier than 19 days is much less than 16%. Recall that for a normal random variable 95% of observations will lie within 2 standard deviations of the mean, and 5% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Correct. This value is 1 standard deviations below the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid earlier than 25 days is 16%. Recall that for a normal random variable 68% of observations will lie within 1 standard deviations of the mean, and 32% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.
Incorrect. This value is the mean, so the percent of bills paid in less than 31 days is 50%. Recall that a normal random variable is symmetric about its mean.

Incorrect. This value is 1 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid earlier than 37 days is much greater than 16%. Recall that for a normal random variable 68% of observations will lie within 1 standard deviations of the mean, and 32% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Incorrect. This value is 2 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid earlier than 43 days is much greater than 16%. Recall that for a normal random variable 95% of observations will lie within 2 standard deviations of the mean, and 5% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.

Incorrect. This value is 3 standard deviations above the mean of 31 days, so the percent of bills paid earlier than 13 days is much greater than 16%. Recall that for a normal random variable 99.7% of observations will lie within 3 standard deviations of the mean, and 0.3% will lie outside this range. This amount is split equally between the upper and lower tails of the distribution.
